title: Denver HIV Risk Score
description: Predicts probability of undiagnosed HIV infection in patients aged 13 and older using demographic and behavioral risk factors.

parameters.name: age_group
parameters.description: Patient age group with variable point assignments

parameters.name: race_ethnicity
parameters.description: Race/ethnicity (optional parameter for additional risk stratification)

result.name: hiv_risk_assessment
result.description: Denver HIV Risk Score with probability assessment and screening recommendations

ranges.description: Very low probability of undiagnosed HIV infection
ranges.interpretation: HIV prevalence approximately 0.31%. Routine screening may be considered based on clinical judgment and patient preferences. Focus on prevention education and risk reduction counseling.

ranges.description: Low probability of undiagnosed HIV infection
ranges.interpretation: HIV prevalence approximately 0.41%. Offer HIV testing and prevention counseling. Consider periodic rescreening based on ongoing risk factors.
ranges.recommendation: Offer HIV testing and prevention counseling

ranges.description: Moderate probability of undiagnosed HIV infection
ranges.interpretation: HIV prevalence approximately 0.99%. Strongly recommend HIV testing and comprehensive prevention counseling. Consider frequent rescreening for persistent risk factors.

ranges.description: High probability of undiagnosed HIV infection
ranges.interpretation: HIV prevalence approximately 1.59%. Urgent HIV testing recommended with comprehensive risk assessment and prevention counseling. Consider expedited testing and linkage to care protocols.

ranges.description: Very high probability of undiagnosed HIV infection
ranges.interpretation: HIV prevalence approximately 3.59%. Immediate HIV testing essential with comprehensive prevention services and linkage to care. Consider same-day testing and expedited results.

clinical_applications: Targeted HIV screening in emergency departments and urgent care
Risk stratification in primary care and community health settings
Resource allocation for HIV testing programs
Public health surveillance and outbreak investigation
Clinical decision support for HIV testing protocols

very_low_risk: Consider routine screening per CDC guidelines
Document risk assessment in medical record
Follow standard screening intervals if no risk factors
low_risk: Offer HIV testing with informed consent
Consider annual screening if ongoing low-level risk
Educate about HIV transmission and prevention
moderate_risk: Discuss risk reduction strategies and safer practices
high_risk: Urgent HIV testing with expedited results
very_high_risk: Immediate HIV testing with same-day results if possible
Frequent screening (monthly to quarterly) if negative
Prioritize for PrEP evaluation and initiation
Intensive case management and support services

references: Haukoos JS, Hopkins E, Conroy AA, et al. Derivation and validation of the Denver Human Immunodeficiency Virus (HIV) risk score for targeted HIV screening. Am J Epidemiol. 2012;175(8):838-846. doi: 10.1093/aje/kwr389.

Hsieh YH, Jung JJ, Shahan JB, et al. Validation of an abbreviated version of the Denver HIV risk score for prediction of HIV infection in an urban emergency department. Acad Emerg Med. 2014;21(7):757-767. doi: 10.1111/acem.12413.

Haukoos JS, Lyons MS, Lindsell CJ, et al. Derivation and validation of the Denver Human Immunodeficiency Virus risk score for targeted HIV screening in emergency departments. Am J Epidemiol. 2012;175(8):838-846. doi: 10.1093/aje/kwr389.
Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. Screening for HIV infection: US Preventive Services Task Force recommendation statement. JAMA. 2019;321(23):2326-2336. doi: 10.1001/jama.2019.6587.
formula: Denver HIV Risk Score = Age Points + Gender Points + Sexual Practice Points + Injection Drug Use Points + Past HIV Testing Points + Race/Ethnicity Points (optional)
notes: Score validated for patients aged 13 and older
Derived from sexually transmitted disease clinic and emergency department populations
Race/ethnicity parameter is optional and may be omitted based on clinical or institutional policies
Low score does not eliminate possibility of HIV infection
Consider clinical context and individual risk factors not captured by the score
Tool intended to supplement, not replace, clinical judgment
Effectiveness of targeted screening varies by population and setting
Consider local HIV prevalence and resource availability
Score may require recalibration for different populations or geographic areas
Regular updates may be needed as HIV epidemiology evolves

validation.population: Patients aged 13 and older seeking care in clinical settings
validation.evidence_basis: Derived and validated in US clinical populations with external validation studies
validation.clinical_utility: Validated tool for targeted HIV screening with demonstrated cost-effectiveness compared to universal screening
